diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum or fifth disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Malignancy (such as lung cancer or lymphoma)
Infectious diseases (such as HIV or cytomegalovirus infection)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems in the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including arthritis, kidney inflammation (nephritis), affects on the brain (psychosis), heart (pericardial effusion), and blood (leukopenia).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily causing arthropathy, rheumatoid arthritis can sometimes lead to pericardial effusion, leukopenia, and very rarely nephritis and neuropsychiatric manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is characterized by features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE, presenting symptoms such as arthropathy, nephritis, and potentially, pericardial effusion and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting salivary and lacrimal glands, Sjögren's syndrome can cause systemic issues such as arthritis, nephritis, and rarely, pericardial effusion and leukopenia. It's uncommon for psychosis to be directly related.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: There are several types of vasculitis, but systemic forms like Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) can cause kidney problems (nephritis), joint pain (arthropathy), and more rarely, heart and hematological issues, including leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: This is lupus-like syndrome that occurs due to long-term use of certain drugs and can cause symptoms similar to SLE, including pericardial effusion, arthropathy, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: This is specifically the kidney involvement in SLE, but patients can also experience other systemic symptoms associated with lupus, including pericardial effusion, arthropathy, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can affect multiple body parts causing arthropathy, and potentially affecting the kidneys, heart (pericardial effusion), and blood (leukopenia). Psychosis isn't a common manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease can involve multiple systems, though it is less commonly associated with nephritis. It can cause arthritis, and very rarely, pericardial effusion and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease can cause arthritic symptoms, leukopenia, and pericardial effusion. Renal involvement is unusual, and psychosis is not typically associated with it.

diagnoses: Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system
Infectious diseases with autoimmune manifestations (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Felty's Syndrome
Infectious Diseases (e.g., bacterial, viral, fungal infections causing systemic involvement)
Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE, affecting multiple organ systems)
Rheumatological Conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis causing pericarditis and other systemic manifestations)
Neoplastic Diseases (e.g., cancers with paraneoplastic syndromes affecting the nervous system and kidneys)
Drug or Toxin-Induced Conditions (e.g., adverse reactions to medications or substances causing multi-organ involvement)
Metabolic Disorders (e.g., uremia from renal failure leading to various systemic manifestations)
Inflammatory Conditions (e.g., sarcoidosis affecting multiple body systems)
Vasculitis (e.g., systemic vasculitis such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis with multi-organ involvement)
Inherited Genetic Disorders (e.g., disorders leading to metabolic derangements affecting multiple organs)
Endocrine Disorders (e.g., severe thyroid diseases with systemic impact)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can affect the skin, joints, heart, and the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or kissing disease, a viral infection that causes fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph glands, especially in the neck.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer originating from lymphocytes, causing symptoms such as lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms include enlarged lymph nodes, fever, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV causes AIDS and interferes with the body's ability to fight infections. It can be transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen, or vaginal fluids.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet, accompanied by fatigue and fever.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are small areas of inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. Symptoms include a bad cough that lasts 3 weeks or longer, pain in the chest, coughing up blood or sputum, weakness, weight loss, fever, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The loss of kidney function over time. Abnormal electrolytes can be one of the signs of its progression, alongside symptoms like high blood pressure, changes in the amount of urine, and electrolyte imbalances.

diagnoses: Carbohydrate malabsorption (e.g., lactose intolerance, fructose malabsorption)
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) / Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection / COVID-19
Malignancies such as lymphoma or leukemia

Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
